How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not

Strengths are the homework and discussion sections. They require us to do work which is good. The course itself is presented in a way that makes sense and makes it easy to learn. Weaknesses are that they could do a better job explaining what they want from us on exams. Some questions can be tricky
Good
Strengths: very clear expectations, assignments, and lecture structure. Slides are explicit and course policies are clear, fair exams.
Strengths: really facilitates learning of epidemiology, designed very well.
It's great as an introduction to epi for someone totally new to the public health area. The workload is reasonable and the lectures are interesting.

Really helpful course. 
Sections were helpful.
Excellent
Great pacing! I enjoyed it.
It is a great foundational course
I think that some of the exam questions are not very clearly worded, which is a real problem.
The course is great for students without any medical background. It is basic and be organized very well.
Well taught and organized
Good
great course, learned all the fundamentals. Somewhat unfair grading.

Good. epi at the threshold level. aroused my interest in further learning.
The classroom (Harkness) was very uncomfortable for a two-hour test.
I really enjoyed this class. I think Professor Niccolai has refined her course well and I really have no criticisms. I felt the exams were fair and the homeworks were challenging but in a good way.
This is a very good intro to epidemiology-- something I knew essentially nothing about walking in, and that I now feel like I have a good foundation in.

Strengths: Weekly homework, weekly small group discussions, Great instructor 
Weaknesses: Timing of lectures, Homework due day after lecture, minimal interaction with instructor

Overall, I am extremely impressed by this course. I have to say I had no expectations going into it, and I was really impressed coming out of it. This ended up being my favorite course, even though I started out being annoyed that I had to take it. I really appreciate how organized prof. Niccolai and tfs were. Made it easy to learn

The only thing I would change is that the readings are  not really beneficial.  theyre either really long studies that we had no need to read or theyre the epi book that is word for word summarized in lecture. Tbh I stopped doing readings midway through the course and I dont think it hurt. But it could be cool if we had more modern papers to read each week where you were explicitly like  hey these researchers effed up and have a ton of bias- find it?

Also I really really appreciate having the formula sheet. I think it helped me focus on the right stuff- the concepts. I would mayyybe just tell ppl a whole chi square calculation wont be on either exam bc ppl definitely spent hours of their lives doing that when they didnt need to. It is covered in bio stats in a different way and you can still test the application.
good
Great course!

Its strengths include the fact that it effectively encompasses and reviews key concepts and potential applications, that a foundational epidemiology course should do. I think this class would benefit from an additional assignment that allows students to apply these concepts to develop their own study.
It is a very useful class. I rarely used the book, so I was not a fan of having to purchase it. The lecture slides were informative. The tests were tricky but the final was fair. Not easy, but fair.

I appreciated that when the Professor was introducing a new concept in class she would include the more traditional verbal or quantitative explanation but would also immediately after present a pictorial, as this is how I learn best. Whenever I went to office hours she carefully listened to my questions, validated my confusion, and then went step-by-step to explain in a new way. Although she did teach inline with the textbook, lecture always provided substantial material outside the textbook. For example, the Professor often cited studies conducted by Yale faculty and researchers. She also broke down the density of scientific articles to offer recommendations of why the author may have made a certain format or analytical choice, asked us to identify the concepts we were learning within the article, and offer potentially problematic study design or reporting choices made by researchers and the consequences of those choices. This was valuable to begin thinking about what kind of studies and writing I wanted to learn and produce. All of her exams were very fair for the material we were learning, even for students with no previous epidemiology experience, like me. Lastly, it was helpful she hosted review sessions prior to exams that felt in line with the kinds of problems we were given on the exams. 

I would have liked to see lectures include more poll questions. The Professor did try to incorporate the technology but it did not always work. I also understand why she left some lecture slides blank given she posted them prior to class, but I would have preferred to not have slides posted until after lecture if that meant the material would have been included.

I loved the class - material was good and interesting, the pace of the class was good as well. Loved the use of articles to prove points that were taught in the textbook; some of it is confusing just in that public health itself is confusing and can sometimes not have a clear answer.
I learnt a lot, and really enjoyed the class.
I think it introduces foundation of epi in a very understanable and systematical way. It's very useful and I learn a lot.
strengths: very comprehensive
Eh, not my favorite subject but no strong feelings. Good structure, helpful homework assignments and well spaced workload.

Strength: organization of information.  It was VERY clear (clearer than any class at YSPH) what we needed to know and were expected to study. With a busy schedule, this is worth everything to me.
Weakness: a bit tedious, with professor reading off slides.
The course is very straight-forward look at epidemiology studies. I think the courses could be shortened into 2-50 minute session as the classes felt way too long for the material that was covered.

The course was well-structured, and the labs at the end of the week were very helpful in reviewing and synthesizing the material. 
I understand why lectures are not recorded, but I think it would be helpful to have recordings for reviewing the material. I am not always able to write everything down, and hearing the instructor talk through concepts is helpful in understanding them.
Amazing. My favorite class where I learned the most and enjoyed it throughly. Strengths are the professor, HW, and TFs. The structure should not change since it was great. NO weaknesses.

strength: excellent. Professor explain material clearly. 
homework is useful to review what we learn in the week.
It was a good and insightful course. Extremely important to take to enter the field of public health
It's fine. I think the real life examples/applications made it better.

I really enjoyed this course. It was immensely challenging, but immensely rewarding. And as a public health student, it is of vital importance to have a strong foundation in this subject to continue on in this career. This course will provide that.
Overall, I had a fantastic time in this class.  While the material was often challenging, with enough review it was achievable and I deeply appreciated the practice problems and comprehensive slides.

Get the general ideas of epidemiology. Why we want to design the study the way it is, what kinds of measures could be used, and how to interpret the finding of the scientific papers. These were very helpful. 

The workload is a bit high. Many homeworks and exams. The class size is big, so it will be really hard for every student to engage and ask related questions during the lecture.

strengths: the discussion sections 
weaknesses: the homework was sometimes too lengthy and vague.

Maybe have three midterms and make the final out of less points. The second midterm for this class felt like an overload of material, and a 40% final is always nerve-wracking and perhaps not representative of a students actual knowledge of the material.
I really enjoyed this course and felt like I learned a lot about epidemiology. This was one of the most useful first-year courses I took this semester.

Strength: Really well structured with embedded review time. I truly think this is one class that I will leave retaining the knowledge I acquired. 

Weakness: The discussion section was a waste of time, energy, and resources.

Fantastic course.  Difficult to recall any other course in which I learned so much in so little time.  I wish the homework problems were more reflective of the test questions, but other than that, no complaints!  Thank you for a great semester!
The course was very well-taught and organized effectively. I gained a very solid understanding of the material and I do not think there needs to be improvement. The course was excellent!

This course was great. It provided a fantastic introductory look into the field of epidemiology, and provided students with the skills to appropriately analyze research papers and epi-related claims made in media (which I find myself doing more of now). In terms of the structure of the class, I appreciated the emphasis on understanding concepts rather than rote memorization of formulas, and applying these concepts to real-world examples in class and on homework assignments, as well as hypothetical examples on homework assignments and exams. I also liked that the homework assignments were graded pass/fail on "a good faith effort to complete the assignment," which definitely took the pressure off of getting the right answer and allowed me to focus on learning the material, viewing the homework assignments as "practice opportunities." Overall, this structure definitely helped me to learn and retain the material very well. In fact, I ended up using the statistics-related material taught in this course to help understand the same concepts taught in other courses. 

In terms of improvement, I thought that some of the homework questions were a bit confusingly worded, especially when learning about confounding and effect modification for the first time. For next year, I might recommend adjusting these questions to start with a very basic step-by-step approach to confounding and then assessing more complicated questions after that.

This was a good class and a nice intro to basic epidemiological topics. It was well organized and I felt like I learnt a lot. The exams were fair. I thought the psets could have had better questions that encouraged more critical thinking.
Very well organized and provides information pertinent to our work in the public health sector.

This course was really great! I think it really does a great job at teaching us how to design studies and gives those who plan to become epidemiologists or epidemiology researchers a lot of useful skills. I think that this class is really good at giving useful skills in how to analyze the data as well, especially for those of us who haven't read as many epidemiology research papers and didn't really use calculations such as odds ratio. Even for people who are not in the epidemiology department, this class was really great at serving as an introduction to what epidemiology is and what wide scope uses it has.
Loved it, just wish it wasn't at 8:30am.
This course gave me thorough understanding of epidemiology and general public health concepts. Wasn't a great class but also wasn't a bad class. I think it taught me what I needed to know.
I loved this course. I had taken epi before but learned a lot this time around. Loved the discussion and homework format and lectures/exams
lecture slides were somewhat hard to follow, even vague sometimes. but overall good class!

This course was very well structured. The homework helped me to asses what I knew/didn't know, lectures were easy to follow, and I always knew what I should/shouldn't be studying for exams. 

The only weakness was the lack of practice problems, but Professor Niccolai addressed this early into the semester.
The course is designed well, and the professor is well prepared; The TA's were extremely helpful, and I found the concepts interesting.
It's a wonderful course and has taught me so much about specific studies and bias. I'm not an epidemiology student but really felt as though I got a core foundation for my own concentration.
good.
I really like the discussion section of this course. It's a very good method for helping students better understanding the knowledge.
More midterm exams. Final was weighed too heavily.

In all honesty, this course is a bit dull. The instructor largely reads off of the slides and the need to attend discussion sections was a bit inconvenient.  That being said, the end of the course became more interesting and maybe the only way to teach basic epidemiology is to really simplify things and check understanding in discussion sections?
An accelerated option for advanced students should definitely be offered.

I really enjoyed this class. I feel like I learned a lot of tangible skills and have a good foundation of epidemiology. A big strength of the course for me was the homework assignments. I think it is both important and useful to have a "skills check" once a week before moving on to new material.

strength: homework was not graded for accuracy and was fairly useful; covered quite a bit of new material 
weakness: exam questions were unclear, professor not accessible (would not respond to emails), too large of a class and poor classroom
I thought the content was very straightforward and workload was manageable. My TA was also a great instructor. Discussion section was a useful supplement.
Lectures are very comprehensive and engaging to follow along. Discussion sections are effective for going over the material and homework assignments.
Both the professor and TFs were incredible for this course!

The strengths were that it was well organized, there were plenty of review sessions provided at the end of the semester, and the book and professor had aligned understandings of the material.
The weaknesses were that sometimes it felt as if the book material was simply being repeated as opposed to explained in a different manner, some of the homeworks were also unhelpful when preparing for the exams. Another downside is how awkward it is to have class in such a large room--it discourages questions and creating real-time examples.

Strength: discussion section 

Weakness: more homework problems that are similar to exams

This class is my favorite class this semester! Lectures and sections were super organized and clear. Practice tests were super helpful, and I appreciate that the instructors (the TFs and the professor) had review sessions for students before an exam. Epi can be difficult to learn, but the class was so clear and I was able to learn epi well with so much joy. I definitely feel like I actually learn something new, useful, and important from the course.
The course taught me essential knowledge in epidemiology and a very organized way, and I was able to implement this knowledge in other courses and research work.

This course gives you some basic epi literacy and skills. Lectures were not engaging and you did not need to go to them. You could do well on exams by just reading the slide decks and re-working homework problems and exam practice problems. I was not motivated to go to class or discussion at all.
Wonderful course, very organized, the material is presented in a streamlined manner so that it builds upon itself.
Great information, easy to understand.
A well oiled machine.  Weekly homework forced us not to get behind the material.
I would encourage her to opt for a project in lieu of one of the tests in order to create learning opportunities for different learning styles and exercising different skills.

The course was wonderful. As a student concentrating in chronic disease epi I found it to be very interesting, but my peers in other concentrations shared similar feelings as well. The course has so much taught in it and the structure of exams and detailed homework foster an amazing chance to engage in the material while actively learning. Cannot think of many ways to improve other than finding a way to reduce the total weight of the final exam.
I thought it was fun! Really enjoyed that the problem sets weren't for a grade, I felt like I was learning to learn!

I think the material itself could be a little dry and consequently makes students zone out/lose interest. I highly recommend against making it an 8:30am class. The instructor made the material more interesting in spite of that. It would also be better to learn the material in a practical manner instead of learning it through memorizing what is out there...for example actually doing a research beginning to end and then seeing the different components throughout, though practically speaking, not sure how that would work. Overall, felt pretty detached from the subject, but not the instructor's fault.

The design of the course works very well. The discussion session was very valuable and the lectures very well organized. One improvement would be to make the lectures available on video the way the other courses do.
The course was interesting and the statistics portion of the course helped in other courses.

I think Dr. Niccolai does a wonderful job teaching the material. Her slides are very thorough and informative and then the TFs do a great job re-establishing the material to us during the discussion and during our homework.

Strengths: material is presented in a way that makes a lot of sense, and it is very clear how it would be applied.

Weakness: Honestly I thought being given a formula sheet let me be too lazy and not really learn some things I really should have learned.
This course was great! It was very well organized, and Dr. Niccolai is a great instructor.

Strengths: great instructor, great source of materials (textbook, mostly lecture slides, homework relevant to exams); had a great TA but that was my own experience, can't speak to how other TA's were for people

Weakness: exam 2 covered a lot more than exam 1; wonder if that could be balanced somehow
Great course.
The course was extremely well instructed and structured. It is clear that Linda has lots of experience and is passionate about this topic/course.
Very good-detailed and informative. Test questions were tricky. TAs were great
Great!

I absolutely loved this course! I feel as though I learned research and analytical skills that I can carry with me throughout the rest of my courses at YSPH as well as in life. The only weakness was at the beginning of the semester before the first exam, there were not enough practice problems to prepare for the exam. However, this was fixed for the second exam and final exam.
Organized structure of lecture and corresponding homework during discussion was helpful- students knew what to expect.
Homework assignment and structure of sections was very helpful. The review before each exam was also helpful.

the lecture format was great . I appreciated having access to the lecture slides before class to take notes with. Having extra problems before the exam with review classes was also extremely beneficial, in addition to the TF reviews.  Having different scientific articles to reflect the different material we were studying kept it interesting
The course was a good and basic intro to epidemiology. Professor was great. It was a bit accelerated, so it had to cover a lot of ground.

Strengths: Discussion sections and Textbook 
Weaknesses: Early Time of the course
strength: weekly homework that hone in the concepts taught and great powerpoint and teaching style of dr. nicolas

Overall the class was a good intro to epi class. However I do believe that some of the material was really rushed. There should have been less content with more time being spent on each certain topic. Also I thought exam 2 covered too material and should have been split up into two exams. I did like the discussion section to get further questions and I thought my tf was fantastic!
fundamental and useful

The course was very well organized. All material was communicated clearly and effectively. The weekly homework was time intensive but also forced me to learn the material and actually understand the class. I have no criticisms of the course.

Strengths - it taught me the foundation of public health and the basics of this field. It also helped to learn about classic case studies from public health history. 

Weaknesses - it was easier to learn the mathematical concepts on my own unfortunately I left more confused sometimes from lecture or discussion. I understood the concepts and the equations but kept getting the answers wrong so I've felt like I either do know or don't know the content at all.
very helpful

Strengths - great comprehensive overview of epi for all majors, discussion sections helped to facilitate learning and provide an extra resource if you needed help

Weaknesses - more case studies would have been helpful to make it a more practical course

Strength instructor
Weaknesses lecture size
Great. It introduced basic concepts on epidemiology and the course structure is good.
The course materials are solid and cover all aspects of the foundation of epidemiology.

As a class teaching fundamentals of epidemiology, I was expecting a broad survey course that would be fairly 'cookie-cutter.' Linda Niccolai's class was very engaging and interesting. She is a careful teacher, and really drives conceptual learning of the field. She also draws examples from across the disciplines to ground her class -- and many of her examples are from Yale faculty, so it's nice to learn about the work of other faculty at Yale. The homework assignments especially are FANTASTIC -- I really felt like they challenged me to think critically about the concepts in class.

Great class. I learned a lot. I enjoyed lectures the most as the professor is highly engaging. I don't have any suggestions for improvements as everything the professor did has been an improvement compared to Epi II and Epi III. The structure of this course was better and posed less stress on students.
The course was structured very well, HW and discussion complemented lecture and Linda was also open during office hours.

I found this course to be extremely comprehensive and well paced. I thought the material built well on itself. The only critique I would have is that with math aspects of the lectures it would be helpful if she showed the work/steps it took to come to the answers provided so I could replicate the process in the homework.
Very well organized. Very clear. Course goals were very clear. Going through examples in class was incredibly helpful. The homeworks reinforced my learning.
It is an overall good course.
learn a lot

I loved this course. I learned so much, and learned it in a way that I can apply and critically think about the material. I felt like I learned and retained the most information from this class. The structure is great and set out very straight.
This course gives a nice introduction to epidemiology. The slides are very clear and well prepared. Questions appeared in homework and exams give the right amount of intellectual challenge.
great and help me to have a basic understanding of epi
This was a great survey course. I learned alot.

strength: the TA section with Tyler was great
Weakness: Class size too big

The problems sets were helpful in making sure I understood each week's material. The textbook was great, and it provided in depth explanations of the concepts covered in the class. It helped more than other resources when I was studying for the exams. I thought the difficulty level of the exams was fair.
Its fairly easy class
good
The course was well organized and lectures were very useful for exams.
You cover and learn a lot. Professor Niccolai is great at presenting the material and gets excited over the material.
The lectures and homework assignments prepares you for the exams.
Prof. Niccolai provides really detailed and organized slides. The weekly assignments and discussion sessions are good for students to strengthen the knowledge learnt from class. I like this course.
The lectures were well-designed. TA led discussion sessions were also very helpful. Overall, it's an easy course, wish more practical or advanced topics could be covered.
Fundamental course for epi, useful introductory course
The course emphasizes more on concepts and definitions. I would prefer to spend more time in reading contemporary researches instead of preparing exams for these detailed things.
This is an excellent course and I only wish we could have a better time and location to take the course. It was too early in the morning and the classroom is somehow dark that makes me feel sleepy.

The lectures were great! very straightforward and easy to understand - albeit very very fast paced. However, the size of the course was not conducive to any kind of conversation or discussion - a major weakness that did not help with understanding. I wonder if this class could be recorded in the future - the lecture slides were very helpful but given Dr Niccolai's pace, it was often hard to keep up. 
Overall, good foundation/introductory course - I went in not knowing a lot/anything about epidemiology and left with a good foundation.
it's a pretty good course - easy because it's simple and straightforward, but also useful material

Course is fundamental, not very quantitative. Good for beginners. 
Good in the structure, information and materials offered 
Weak in critical thinking, too narrow of some criteria

Video recording for lecture would help those who learn best by podcasting and rewinding multiple times. 

Though I can empathize with the  instructors desire for class participation ,
the Lack of recording wont necessarily cause students ( especially those who have a prior Epi background) to attend.

I thought this was a wonderful course and very well taught by both Dr. Niccolai and my teaching fellow Lizzie White. I appreciated the exam reviews that the TFs conducted before exams. I do wish that the class was taught in smaller groups.

The homework discussion part was a good way for me to better understand  the knowledge learned in class. As for the class materials, I think they were not organized well, especially compared with the materials of other schools like Boston University. And also, some important points were not stressed out.
Overall this course is very helpful in understanding basic epidemiological concepts.

I thought this class was good overall. The powerpoints were clear and strong. During review, they were incredibly helpful and straightforward. As well, the homework sessions and TA review sessions were great. I think that the test review sessions were helpful. However, the one weakness of the class is that the first test felt completely separate from the homework. While I understand they are doing different things, the other tests did a good job of integrating class material and some aspects of the homework. Therefore, I feel as if the first unit could do a better job at integrating the class in general.

This course covers a lot of details and is very useful. However, I do feel that understanding is more important than memorizing. Sometimes the exam is so fixated on tiny details for a certain part of knowledge (i.e. designing a retrospective study) that it loses the essence for studying. I mean, if you are doing a research and designing a study, you can certainly look up literature or any materials that corroborates your study design.

Very good introduction and overview of epidemiological concepts. Course was challenging but fair in design. I would recommend recording lectures to make review easier for students who are absent and for those who learn better by listening.
It's a good structured way to learn the basics of epidemiology. I feel I have a good understanding of the material.

I struggled a great deal with this course and came very close to failing, which was (and still is) deeply disappointing. I think there were a number of reasons for this, including:
-General logistical/timing of the class: having epidemiology and biostatistics every morning at 8:30 AM was brutal. I understand that students are all on different schedules, having to be "on" for early morning lectures where the majority of material was read directly off of slides negatively impacted my ability to be productive later in the day. I noticed a marked difference in my overall productivity and ability to study on days where we had off from these 8:30 classes.
-There seemed to be very little consistency between the TFs. Greater uniformity in teaching approach would have been useful, particularly considering this was essentially a 101 course.
-Other students might disagree with me on this, but I would suggest that homework be graded rather than simply pass/fail. I found very little incentive to dedicate the time necessary to understand homeworks each week knowing that I would get credit "just for trying". 
-To that point, short quizzes during TF sections personally would have been a better way to test my understanding of the material. Part of the reason I performed so poorly in the class was due to the few opportunities to express mastery of the material outside of exams.

Lectures can be a little dry, but they get the job done. Having gone into the course with no prior epidemiology background or experience, I definitely learned a lot and feel very confident in my understanding of basic epidemiology. The schedule of lectures are well planned, the homework is reasonable and definitely helps in preparing for exams, and discussion sections are incredibly helpful. Overall, a great introductory course.
This course was my favorite-- I thought the lectures were clear, and this is the first time certain math concepts have made sense to me. I also liked the additional reading resources.
She is very engaging and a great lecturer. She is also really empathetic to her students.
Good

Clearly presents information, is well organized in class so expectations are clear
Being a little more approachable or engaging with students one on one would be nice

Professor Niccolai was a great instructor. Her lecture and slides were very informative, she taught everything she expected us to know, and also was very straightforward with everything. I have no complaints.
Professor Niccolai is really good at teaching this course. She walked us though epi with a lot of interesting cases (or more like stories). That helps me a lot in terms of understanding epi.
She is incredible! I loved how she teach and explain things. Really clear and friendly, open to questions and discussion.
Dr. niccolai cares a lot about the course material, and it is shown by how meticulous the course is taught.
The instructor is very nice and experienced.
Great lecturer
Good
Great and encouraging and helpful with questions.
Very good instructor
I really like Professor Niccolai. I think that she thinks carefully about how to present complex concepts in a clear way to the class. She also related in-class topics back to real world examples.
Approachable. Great teacher!
Organized, thoughtful, committed to teaching. I can tell she has some discomfort/dislike with teach8ng that huge lecture class, but that didnt get in the way of learning.
good
Awesome Lady!
Professor Niccolai is truly knowledgeable in the field of epidemiology and disease surveillance. Most of her exams were fair, just slightly long in duration.
Since she doesn't record her lectures, I wish she would post lecture notes with her lecture slides like Mike does for biostats.

Please see what I wrote above.

Sometimes the Professor did not always feel approachable. That changed for me early on when I spoke with her one-on-one, but I know some students continued to feel that way. She was very personable throughout, especially the second half of the semester. But the very first lecture in which she covered plagiarism and other expectations I think is what set an unapproachable tone for others. Although I do think those feelings were potentially conflated by the fact that the seriousness of plagiarism was heavily covered in orientation and then again in all four core classes in those first two weeks.
Very clear lectures and expectations for exam.
She's great and good at teaching. She's patient.
Nice lady - good teacher.

Very organized, and able to convey the fundamentals of epidemiology.  I appreciate the thought that went into organizing this course so so so much.

My only weakness is that I didnt always feel welcome to ask questions because she made me feel like we should already understand it because she already said it.  She seemed a bit irritated when people would ask her questions, especially if was a) too easy and in the slides or b) too hard and beyond her knowledge and the scope of the class.   Sometimes I perceived she was tired of us!  Haha, probably rightfully so.

Professor Niccolai was incredibly passionate and taught some seemingly complex topics in a concise and easy to understand way. While she is a great epidemiology professor who I would strongly recommend to a classmate, she came off slightly intimidating. The only thing I think should be improved, is more clarification on the specificity she would like on tests.
Professor Niccolai is a great professor. Her powerpoint and lectures are clear.

Dr. Niccolai is well-organized and clear in her delivery of the material. Using the case studies to go over what we have already learned was helpful in understanding how the concepts can be applied to actual studies.
My favorite professor. Amazing.
Strength: professional. Encourage students to engage in class. Teaching style is excellent and professional.
The professor was fair in her assessments and classes.
she's fine. She was stumped by class questions more than I would have expected, which was a little discouraging
She is very knowledgeable and thorough; a good 'explainer' and instructor!  Perhaps would have liked more 'high-level/ summarizing' content during lecture (like at the end of each lecture(.

Dr. Niccolai was a joy to have as a professor. She expects a lot, but is very clear in her teaching and is professional in her delivery. She is quick to answer questions asked of her online, and is very accessible in office hours. I really enjoyed having her as a teacher.
Wonderful at being able to take ideas from students and apply them to what she was talking about. She encouraged the class with open participation, making the class enjoyable and engaging.
I think she is doing great job based on the setting of the class (size, content).
She was great. I liked her teaching style as it was very straightforward. I also thought her exams to be very fair.
Dr. Niccolai is a great instructor but she can sometimes be very critical when students ask questions

She knows what she is talking about and she has a very effective teaching style. I wasn't keen on her at first but she grew on me as she showed that she truly does have a strong understanding of the material and she wants us to succeed. The tests she designed were fair and very reflective of what we had learned in class. I've had nearly 40 instructors over my time at Yale and I'd place Dr. Niccolai in the top 10. Very good!
Clearly passionate and extremely knowledgeable about the course.  I think it would've been good if the lectures were recorded if possible.

Professor Niccolai had very clear lecture slides and explained concepts clearly. She took questions in class and ensured everyone understood what was going on. The exams were comprehensive and clear. Great instruction!

Prof. Niccolai is a GREAT instructor. I took one other epidemiology class in college and did not have a great experience, so I was a little nervous about this class. But Prof. Niccolai was incredibly clear, open-minded, supportive, interesting, engaging, realistic, respectful.... the list goes on. She routinely reminded students of course expectations, and highlighted the "big picture" that she thought we should be getting out of each lecture. 

I don't have any recommendations for Prof. Niccolai to improve her teaching style, but I would like to point out that our lack of engagement in class toward the end of the semester was not you-- many of us just had a very exhausting semester overall.
Professor Niccolai was a good, fair instructor. She was very clear when explaining things and clear as to what her expectations of us were.
Very competent. I enjoyed having her as an instructor.
Professor Niccolai was really great at teaching and explaining hard concepts! She was always very helpful when it came to clarifications. Super great professor!
Dr. Niccolai was great and always very helpful with any questions I had.

Prof Niccolai is clearly a very intelligent and knowledgable faculty. She also definitely has a passion for the material, which made learning about epi more interesting. She sometimes would seem impatient with students when they asked questions in lecture but if you met with her one-on-one she was very nice and helpful.
Linda was amazing. Clearly she knew the material and was passionate. Engages with students. Addresses student questions and concerns.
She is a great lecturer and was very helpful during the office hours!

Professor Niccolai is a wonderful instructor. Her lecture style is clear and easy to follow (although sometimes a little too fast...). I really enjoyed being in lecture not just for the content, but for the additional insights Professor Niccolai provided (e.g. her strong opinions about p-values!). It's clear she enjoys teaching this material and her knowledge and insights made epi that much more enjoyable to learn.
She is a great professor with a wealth of knowledge. I appreciate how she engaged the class and expressed her excitement of the course material.
She is a great professor who is incredibly knowledgeable in her field.
I hope professor Niccola could speak louder. But I really appreciate all the review section we have. I think they are really helpful.

Prof. Niccolai is very patient. Lots of questions could be answered during the class. Besides that, examples mentioned on the classes are very helpful for students better understanding practice problems in public health.
Instructor is difficult to approach.

Linda clearly knows her material. She is excited about her work and teaching. Additionally, she does want students to learn. However, her slides were very unoriginal and sometimes, her explanations of important concepts were lacking clarity.

I enjoyed Dr. Niccolai's teaching style. Her lectures were clear and concise, and her slides are detailed. I really appreciated the many connections to real world epidemiology research and practice. She did a very good job of teaching the concepts in a way that reinforced their real-world applicability.
not great, not terrible. was fairly unapproachable and unclear with exam writing but gave lots of exam preparation and made it easy to do well if you put in the energy
Extremely dedicated and good at explaining things.
Professor Niccolai was a great instructor and made lectures thorough and engaging.
Professor Niccolai teaches wonderfully! Perhaps more practice problems made by the professor.

Dr. Niccolai has a lot of enthusiasm for the course which is really helpful in ensuring that the class is interesting. However, sometimes the explanations feel more like reiteration of the book and not necessarily a different explanation.
She seemed to be really interested in what she was teaching and that definitely helped when I was struggling.

Professor Niccolai is one of the best lecturers at YSPH! I definitely feel that her teaching is appropriate for an introductory course. She's super clear, thorough, and organized. She can go fast sometimes but that's not an issue if you go to office hours. Her lectures were thorough and had great logical flow, and she provided with a lot of examples to illustrate the concepts. She answered students' questions very well in class, and she raised a lot of interesting questions about study designs or examples from the literature that prompted us to think critically. I liked that she didn't want us to think about study designs in black-or-white terms.
Dr. Niccolai is able to teach the material in a very organized way and express herself clearly, which makes learning this unfamiliar material very easy.
I did not interact with Professor Niccolai much. Recording lectures would have made the class more inclusive for students with disability.
WONDERFUL! I have nothing but kind words for Dr. Niccolai. She taught the course beautifully.
Professor Niccolai explains epi concepts in a way that makes it accessible to everyone, and provides wonderful concrete examples to help explain concepts.

Overall a good professor.  You can tell she is a very intense and passionate for her field.  Her biggest strength is that writes a really fair exam.   Her biggest weakness is that she is simply too nice to us--there's any barely equations to memorize and yet, she gave us a cheatsheet for formulas after a student asked.  Any formula sheet should be limited to complicated equations like chi-square test for homogeneity and mentzel-hentzel.
She was very strong. friendly, approachable and really knows her stuff

Professor Niccolai is amazing! She can take something as complex and broad as epi and make it seem both approachable and fascinating. She stresses the importance of asking questions about the work we will be doing, and to take nothing as a given when evaluating things in the real world. She is extremely good at teaching us, always would engage with questions, and never missed an opportunity to follow-up with a question she could not immediately answer. She made epi an amazing experience and left me with the feeling of no matter what grade I end up with, I know I am prepared to be am effective public health professional.
Her slides were amazing and she had everything the students needed from the beginning of the course.
The instructor cares about challenging the students and has put a lot of work into the course materials. Her lectures were engaging and I enjoyed the course very much.
Dr. Niccolai is an engaging instructor whose lectures were very interesting.

Dr. Niccolai is wonderful. I think she is so intelligent and because of that comes of as very intimidating but when you chat with her she's very kind and what's you to succeed! She cares about her students and epidemiology, which is clear when she teaches and just chatting with her.
Dr. Nicolai was a great instructor! Her class was very organized and informational - I learned a lot from it.

Wonderful instructor! I found her to be instructive, knowledgeable, accessible. Strong presence that fostered attentive environment, balanced with genuine regard for students which allows for questions, etc. I don't have negatives to give about her
Great professor who was able to make something dry, engaging.
Linda was an excellent lecturerand overall professor.
I liked Dr. Niccolai. She was forward and straight to the point but she explained everything very clearly.
Prof Niccolai is awesome and a great instructor

Dr. Niccolai was an excellent professor for this course. She explained the material in a clear manner and would answer any questions students had. She also made herself easily accessible and available for students to meet with her for extra help with the material.

Strengths: organized structure (same idea of lecture + corresponding homework each week), powerpoint from lecture was always in the same format and available for refernece. 
Weaknesses: lectures were sometimes confusing because the line of logic that the professor would present throughout material was not very clear. Sometimes, lecture would make the material more confusing that it needed to be due to the professors explanations.
Overall good at communicating material but very intimidating and rude when students asked questions in lecture. Made me not want to speak up in class.
She kept the material interested and described it in a clear concise manner. She was always happy to answer questions and would try and find the answer if she could not directly answer it.
Professor Niccolai was great, and very knowledgeable.

I liked prof. Niccolai teaching style through the lecture PowerPoint format. It was a good way to learn and was a solid way to study and review material. There were not any weaknesses I could think of regarding the prof.
very good
Dr. Niccolai was very well spoken in lecture and communicated very effectively.
Nice instructor.

Linda was very helpful in reaching out to help in any way and knowing that she was very involved in helping my friend to succeed in the course. She wants to see her students succeed. I also understand that it is difficult to reach every student to meet his/her needs but she was very engaging during lectures.
The lectures were not recorded which would have helped for prepping for final examinations. Slides were clear.
very clear
I really enjoyed Professor Niccolai. She was always engaged and provided us with all of the materials we needed to succeed. She was great with answering questions and timely feedback for exams.
Great. Prof. Niccolai's lecture is highly organized and informative.
The lectures are really clear and organized. Professor can explain every detail of the course material.

What can I say about Linda that hasn't already been said about Dr. Rev. MLK Jr., Gandhi, or Ken Rothman. She is a wonderful teacher, is passionate about epidemiology, runs a tight ship, and sets up an environment to truly engage with and learn the material.

Perhaps it would be nice if we could discuss more landmark epidemiological papers as examples in class.
Great teaching

She is fantastic. Great lecturer. Super engaging. I would love to have her teach Epi II and III. She simplifies difficult concepts and finds multiple ways to teach them. She can connect with students well and not make them feel like they are dumb because they can't grasp the concept. This cannot be said of all Epi YSPH professors.

Linda was a great instructor, who conveyed topics of epi very well. I enjoyed learning from her and going to her office hours. However at times she would seem to get flustered with repetitive questions. I would encourage her to remain calm, and realize that repeated questions or probing questions are not a reflection on her, but just from inquisitive students.
I thought she was a very clear and thorough instructor. She was very empathetic when I was struggling and made time to meet with me one on one.
Always on time. Very clear. Super organized. Clearly very knowledgeable.
The instructor is patient and clear. No need to improve.
humorous and impressive

I really enjoyed Dr. Niccolai. I think she is a strong, intelligent woman. She was a no-nonsense kind of professor in the classroom but was very personable and easy to talk to outside. She was always super willing to answer questions, and explain concepts I didn't understand during office hours. She made the material easy to understand. I hope to be a professor like her someday.
Professor Niccolai is a great professor. I love going to her lectures, where she explains the concepts very clearly. Her slides are also very helpful.
Professor Niccolai is very organized and gives great lectures.

This instructor was fair, and she seemed to genuinely care about all of her students. She explained everything in a way that was clear and easily understood. Her presentations and powerpoints were very helpful. She is very open and accessible if you need help.
Dr. Niccolais lecture was pretty clear, the homework problem helps a lot to learn. However, it would be great if there is an updated version of lecture notes available after each class.
She explains things clearly
good
Shes so great! Enthusiastic, smart, and clear.
Dr. Niccolai is very knowledgable in the field of Epidemiology and effectively taught this course.

Dr. Niccolai is very good and experienced at teaching. She encourages students to think and I like the weekly assignments which helps me review and understand the knowledge learned in the week. The exam questions sometimes is a bit confusing which I think may be improved.
Great.
Shes explaining things very clearly and has a quick response to students requirements or questions.
Professional, very patient

Only one thing to note: Dr. Niccolai is not geared mathematically.
For example, there are many instances during lecture (or in the slides), where convenient, but faulty, mathematics is used.
During the additive effect modification examples, she would write something like: "3 < 2+0.1+1.1+1.5 = 4.7, so additive EM present"
One should separate the two equations: "2+0.1+1.1+1.5=4.7 ..... 4.7>3 .... thus, additive EM present"
I get the point, but this is mathematically incorrect, and it confused me many times trying to look through the equation. 

Pedantic, but an error nonetheless.

Prof. Niccolai has a broad knowledge of epidemiology, while she could make our class even better if she could have more preparation in the mechanisms or pathophysiology of the diseases which she chose as examples in class.
I believe she is a great instructor that I cannot think any advice for her. Maybe try to speak louder next time.

Dr Niccolai is incredibly straightforward which i really like and appreciate in an instructor. I thought everything about this class is fair but the pace of the class is quite fast, especially for students with no background in epi and students who have been out of school for a while.

she was good; I didn't go to lecture enough to evaluate her accurately
fortunately, her lecture slides were sufficient for learning the info

Good instructor, good effort, well organized
Improvement in the way of homework, not solid enough

I can you empathize with your challenge of teaching  to those who have no Epi  background at all and  to those who have prior knowledge. 

Then there are those students who approach their MPH course with an undergrad mindset and those who approach them with a med school mindset. The latter is dedicated to learn  in the most efficient manner possible, given the ever present time  constraints & pressure.  

Video recording for lecture would help those who learn best by podcasting and rewinding multiple times. 

Though I can empathize with the  instructors desire for class participation ,
the Lack of recording wont necessarily cause students ( especially those who have a prior Epi background) to attend.
Dr. Niccolai is very good at explaining topics clearly. I think she is a very effective lecturer, and her powerpoint are also very clear and helpful!

Dr. Niccolai did a good job. It was a tough thing to teach in such a large group. I think that she did a good job at explaining all of the information. However, I would recommend doing more practice problems in class. Going through the legionnaire's disease was incredibly helpful to understand the math. As well, her smaller math usages in class helped. However, it would be useful to go through a problem in class together where it was not pre-calculated but rather work through it.

Dr. Niccolai knows what she's doing and generally explains things well. Sometimes she's challenged in class, but she will keep those questions in mind and write an email to us to explain further. She's responsible.

Maybe she could emphasize more on the overarching structure for each lecture. Because EPI contains so much detail, sometimes we will lose track of the big picture.
Excellent instructor with true understanding of and devotion to teaching the material.

I think Professor Niccolai's slides were clear and the case studies she brought up were interesting. However, she is very concerned with keeping the power difference between professor and student very clear which doesn't make any sense for a graduate level class. Also she basically reads off of her slides and when people have detailed questions about the case studies she is often unable to answer them. I find is highly surprising that a professor of this level is presenting data she is unfamiliar with. Often the questions these students asked were easily answered by other students in the class which indicates lack of preparedness on the part of Professor Niccolai.

Professor Niccolai was readily available for questions during and outside of office hours. Unfortunately I often felt as though lectures were read directly off of slides, which often left me feeling like I taught myself most of the material for the course.

Dr. Niccolai clearly knows her stuff, but most importantly she is great at breaking down concepts and information, which is really important for an introductory course. She makes class enjoyable and explains why certain calculations or designs are preferred or used in particular situations over others. Great instructor.

Dr. Niccolai was fantastic. I really appreciate that if she doesn't know the answer to something, she actually says that she doesn't know, and takes the time to find an answer. Her lectures are great, her primary literature selections were always helpful, and I think the tests were always fair. The only criticism I have is that it was difficult to meet with her one-on-one. I had a class during her office hour, and there were times when I had questions the TAs couldn't answer-- they would say that they would pass the question on to Dr. Niccolai, and then I would get no response.
I would recommend it because it is a very organized course that has a lot of useful and meaningful material. You will definitely get out what you put in.
Good
It was a good class. Great way to learn epidemiology. Its not much work. Honestly, as long as you do the homeworks and attend lecture, you can easily learn the information.
Good course, worth the time.

Really good material. Complete and extensive.
Really good professor and TFs.
Really important for public health.
Informative. It is the foundation of Public Health, everyone who has interest in Public Health should take it.
I would recommend it to a fellow student-- was a good way to get introduced to the terminology and concepts of epidemiology.
I would recommend it
It is a very useful course to get to know some basic knowledge for epidemiology, strongly recommend.
This course teaches many important concepts for public health research.
Highly recommended
You need to work hard but will learn a lot.
Yes. it lays a solid foundation for future public health courses.
I would recommend the course to other students. I enjoyed the class and think that Professor Niccolai is a great teacher.
Basic understanding of study designs, confounding and effect modification. Its required.
Yes. But also its required.. but I dont think you should. Graduate with an mph without knowing most of this stuff.
good
Great knowledge for anyone interested in doing research in this field
I would definitely recommend this class to other students due to the foundation it sets.
Very useful.

Yes, I would recommend this class to another student, regardless of it being a core requirement for the program. Mostly because a basic grasp of epidemiology feels incredibly important for anyone in public/global/local health and this course is an easily digestible to do that and over a wide array of topics.
Yes. It's very useful and not too hard.
Required. Provides a good epi background.

This course accomplishes the mission of learning the foundations of epidemiology.  Can be a bit tedious, but its an intro course, so I think its the best it could be.  I didnt know what epidemiology was before this course, and now I can read academic Epi papers and make sense of them....so, success.
Very helpful
I would recommend this course to another student as your understanding of public health research will greatly increase with it.
I think it was an insightful and fair course. Yes, I would recommend this course.
required

The course presents a broad overview of introductory epidemiology. It is a required course and is therefore quite a big class. But in this class you will learn so much  epi is foundational to the study of pubic heath and Dr. Niccolai does an excellent job of communicating the essentials of this discipline in a clear and professional way.

I would recommend it to another student, in part because the material is so pertinent to understanding the public health field and research, in part because the material was actually engaging. 

In summary, this course guided us through the history of epidemiology, providing insight on what tools are available for public health research, how they are used, and what the advantages and disadvantages are with each one.
Yes for students who wants to get an idea of what is epidemiology.
Take it, it was one of the courses at YSPH for me. I learned so much.

It was very fine. The exams were tricky and sometimes were graded in ways that were super subjective which was really irritating considering there were only two and they were both worth a lot. You learn a lot but the assessment style didn't feel very fair to me. I understood the material super well but don't think my grade will reflect that in the end, which is always disheartening.

Yes, I would recommend it. I felt like this course was very organized and fair. I learned a lot and am confident a lot of the material I learned can be applied to what I do in the public health field.

This teaches you the Foundations of Epidemiology. It is as basic as that. It is very well thought out and evenly paced. You should never feel overwhelmed. The homework is a tad cumbersome at times but it doesn't reflect the exams. There is a lot of support built into this class so it is all good!

Difficult, but manageable if you really take the time to learn the material.  Like all grad school courses, there's a lot of material covered in a short period of time, which means you constantly need to take the time to review and learn by yourself, despite the fact that the professor and TA are both very good and helpful.  Professor expects you to fully understand the material, which can feel frustrating, but ultimately is very good for your future knowledge and for actually applying it.  Would recommend to anyone who wants a really solid understanding of epidemiology.
Basic concepts in epidemiology. Yes, I would highly recommend this course!

This course provides an introductory look into the field of epidemiology and equips students with the skills to think critically about epidemiology research in the scope of public health work and in daily life (i.e. debunking claims about "risk" in the media). 

I would recommend this course to every public health student. Epidemiology is a major discipline of public health and I think it is essential that all public health practitioners (even those outside of epidemiology) have a foundational understanding of the material. I am very glad I took this course.
I would recommend it to another student because it establishes a foundational knowledge of epidemiology and its importance in public health.
definitely a necessary course to understand research in public health

I would say that this course is literally the definition of an intro class, which is amazing because I did not know too much about epidemiology. I would definitely recommend this course to someone who likes epi, science, or math. But if math and science isn't your strong suit, may not be the best class as it is pretty theoretical and science heavy. But still a great introductory course!

This course gives you the necessary skills and knowledge to understand epidemiology. It also nicely bridges material from other public health courses. I would definitely recommend this to another student.
Would 100% recommend this course. So informative and I know I have a solid foundation for the next level.
yes! great class
This course provided core epidemiology skills and knowledge that will enhance my studies here at YSPH and beyond. I feel very prepared for future epi courses.
I would recommend. The course is not difficult and it makes for a great introduction to the field.
Yes! Everyone should take this class because it provides a foundation of epidemiology that you can take with you throughout your future.

Yes and no. I have already learned this course before, so I think to some extent our school should consider waive it for students who don't have master degrees but have credit for this class. But I will highly recommend it for students without Public Health background.
Yes! This course is very helpful for knowing public health at the first time.
Builds character.

This course will provide you will an introduction to epidemiology. However, there will be black boxes in the way studies are designed and data analyzed. This course does not get into the "knitty-gritty" of study design etc. For those who are interested in the more nuanced characteristics of epidemiology, this class might be a bit boring.

Absolutely. This was my favorite course this semester. I learned a lot and was challenged, but in a manageable way. I feel like I've walked away with a new skills et, and I think the material was taught in the most effective way possible which I think is impressive for a course as large as it was.
i mean the material and context are necessary for public health but would not retake the course or recommend a student go over of their way to take the course
Id say its a straightforward, comprehensive introduction to epidemiology. If you put the time in, its very manageable. I would recommend it.

This is a great introductory course. Having never been exposed to epidemiology before, I learned a ton. It is nice to see crossovers in material between this course and other courses like biostatistics.
Great course, keep up with the material and you will be fine!
It's kind of required, so you have to take it. For the most part the material is interesting and make sense when thinking of developing studies as a whole.
Excellent course! Very organized, informative, clear, and useful. You'll learn a lot.
I would recommend this course to another student because the content of this course is essential for someone pursuing a public health degree and you can learn a lot from this course.
This class does a good job of helping you understand basics of epi, but there is nothing exciting or engaging about the material.
Yes, would recommend only if taught by Dr. Niccolai.
Highly recommend to non-PH students (PH students are required to take this course).  Actually a well thought-out course.  And will you a well-rounded introduction to epidemiology

The course in an in depth overview of the main topics pertinent to epidemiology. I would recommend it to any student going into a health care related field. You learn more than topics, you learn how to actively evaluate and question the research and work being done in the world.

I can see how it's absolutely necessary and vital to take this for public health, but there must be other creative ways to present the material to the students. It felt more memorization heavy and not sure how long the material would stick. Not sure what an alternative would look like...
This course teaches basic concepts of epidemiology and public health. I would highly recommend to another student.

I struggled with the material, but once I got a hang of it at the end, I really enjoyed the class and that is especially thanks to our discussion groups and our TFs. I would definitely recommend this class to another student if Dr. Niccolai is teaching it, because you will learn epidemiology at the end of the day.

I would definitely recommend! After taking epidemiology, I feel I can better evaluate the merit of studies/conduct a study in my own research interests. I am a better public health student and even a better patient for being able to read about diseases that affect me with an astute eye.
Yes.
Yes-tougher than you expect but a very good class. makes me wanna take more epidemiology classes
Would definitely recommend

Great course that really establishes the foundations of epidemiological concepts and analysis tools. I definitely learned things in this class I will carry with me throughout my career in public health.
I would recommend it because Epi is an essential public health course.
This course was essentially its title, the foundations of epidemiology for public health. Yes I would recommend as an intro course for a public health student.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student. It is a great introductory course to epidemiology that professor Niccolai makes entertaining and and engaging.

I would recommend this course for students who want to get a general grasp on epi. It was quite work intensive compared to other introduction classes but I believe it was worthwhile in the end. There could have been some improvements here and there but for any newcomer to the epi field this would be a solid class to take.
very useful! I would strongly recommend the course!

This course taught me the fundamentals of epidemiology and some of the course ties into other classes, such as Biostatistics. I can walk away from the course saying that I am able to read a research paper and understand the design and qualitative assessment.
Useful course.

I would definitely recommend this course to a student as it is a foundational course for public health degree. I would describe it as an epidemiology 101 type course teaching every kind of study design and it utilized a lot of descriptive epidemiology concepts and equations.
Wonderful, tackled some important topics in PH
worth taking, very helpful

This course is a great overview of epidemiology and related research. Upon completion of the course I feel as though I can critically think about research thats been done or is being done and its impact on public health, its implications for the field, and how valid the study is both internally and externally in terms of generalizability. I would highly recommend!
This course introduced the basic concepts in epidemiology. I would recommend.
I highly recommend this course. You will learn a lot.

Yes, it's a class you will have to take in public health, but for what it's worth, Linda makes it wonderful. Her slides are great (a little bare bones, but that makes it all the more important and useful to go to lecture -- it's worth it!), the book is helpful for solidifying concepts, and the homework assignments stretch your thinking of epidemiology. If you engage with the material, there is so much to learn from this class!
Yes

I liked the course and would recommend it to students looking to develop a strong foundation of basic epi concepts. The fact that attendance and HWs are graded more flexibility, makes you want to learn more without the added stress of getting a grade.
Great introduction to EPI. I would recommend it to every student.
It is a course which provides the necessary information we need to know for epidemiology. I would recommend.,
Yes. It is very useful for public health student.
I loved this course. And was kind of sad when it finished.
I highly recommend this class to any students who would like to gain a solid background in introductory epidemiology.
Yes I would recommend it to students who are interested in knowing something about epidemiology.
This was a great class, although a good amount of work to really understand how to solve every problem. This class is obviously very important for everyone in YSPH. I highly recommend it.
It provided a good introduction to someone new to public health and had little prior exposure in medical journals.
Yes, she is really helpful.

I would recommend this course to a students with little to no background in epidemiology and wishes to establish a foundational understanding of the subject. I learned a lot of material in just a semester.
Yes a useful and easy class
good
A good introductory course to epidemiology.
Great thorough intro to epi. Hard work but worth it.
This class gives a very good introduction to the field of Epidemiology for public health students. I will recommend it to another student.
I will recommend this course to a fellow student. Epi is the fundamental knowledge for public health students and Dr. Niccolai does a great job teaching.
This course is a great entry level epidemiology course and teaches many very useful concepts regarding public health.
I would recommend it to students who have interest at epi.
The epidemiology is the cornerstone of public health. Thus, I would recommend other students taking this course.
It is a great course and you need to take it for entering public health area.

Despite it being a mandatory core course, i would recommend it to students because the overview of the topics/subjects is very interesting. But I would encourage them to seek a TF that works for them - and not be shy to switch sections or speak up if its not working, like I wish I had done.

required for YSPH so yes
if you have any experience in epi though, you can't probably test out of it with a little extra studying - not a difficult course
Good for beginners,
I would only recommend the course if one seeks to refine / reinforce ones foundational Epi understanding. Often feels like busy work, but punctuated golden nuggets of new knowledge.

This is the most basic course for us epidemiology students. Since I've learned epi in undergraduate school, I expected this course to be better. It did illustrated some important points but how it was organized  somewhat disappointed me.

This class is a good overview of the basic principle of epidemiology. It is a first step into the world of epidemiology. Overall, I would say that it is useful to know, especially as a complement to the material of other classes.

it's a must-take for public health students, and it's useful. It lays the foundation for a lot of classes. So just take it!
But if you are not interested in public health, the materials could be less engaging.
Very good learning experience.
A good course on the basics of epidemiology. It's certainly not inspiring or groundbreaking but you will learn the fundamentals of the material.

This course is Epidemiology 101. It's necessary as a foundational course for public health, so it's difficult for me to NOT recommend it -- that said, had I known that I could test out of it in advance of the program, I likely would have taken the course at another institution before arriving at Yale to free up my time and mental space for an additional elective course.
Overall, a great class introducing students to the different types of epidemiological study design types and measures.
